title: Virgil
summary: Publius Vergilius Maro (70–19 BC), known as Virgil, was the greatest poet of ancient Rome — author of the *Aeneid*, the Roman national epic, the *Eclogues*, and the *Georgics*. His *Aeneid* became the central text of Latin education for two thousand years, and his influence on Western literature — from Dante to Milton — is second only to Homer.
author: EduWiki Team

title: Michelangelo
summary: Michelangelo di Lodovico Buonarroti Simoni (1475–1564) was the supreme genius of the Italian Renaissance — sculptor, painter, architect, and poet — whose works *David*, the *Pietà*, and the Sistine Chapel ceiling stand among the greatest achievements in the history of human art.
author: EduWiki Team

title: Petrarch
summary: Francesco Petrarca (1304–1374), known as Petrarch, is celebrated as the "Father of Humanism" — the Italian poet and scholar who first articulated the Renaissance ideal of recovering classical wisdom. His *Canzoniere* established the Petrarchan sonnet as the dominant lyric form in European poetry for three centuries.
author: EduWiki Team

title: Geoffrey Chaucer
summary: Geoffrey Chaucer (c. 1343–1400) was the greatest English poet of the Middle Ages and the "Father of English Literature" — the first major writer to use the English vernacular for serious literary art. His masterpiece, *The Canterbury Tales*, creates a panoramic portrait of medieval English society in all its variety, humor, pathos, and moral complexity.
author: EduWiki Team

title: Miguel de Cervantes
summary: Miguel de Cervantes Saavedra (1547–1616) was the greatest writer in the Spanish language and the author of *Don Quixote* (1605/1615) — widely considered the first modern novel and one of the greatest works of literature ever written. His story of the idealistic knight-errant Don Quixote founded the tradition of the novel itself.
author: EduWiki Team

title: Erasmus
summary: Desiderius Erasmus of Rotterdam (c. 1466–1536) was the greatest Christian humanist of the Renaissance — a Dutch scholar, theologian, and satirist whose *In Praise of Folly*, Greek New Testament, and educational writings shaped the intellectual landscape of 16th-century Europe and helped prepare the way for the Protestant Reformation.
author: EduWiki Team

title: Raphael
summary: Raffaello Sanzio da Urbino (1483–1520), known as Raphael, was one of the three supreme masters of the Italian High Renaissance, celebrated for the serene beauty and compositional clarity of his paintings. His *School of Athens* — depicting the great philosophers of antiquity — is one of the defining images of Western intellectual culture.
author: EduWiki Team

title: Rembrandt
summary: Rembrandt Harmenszoon van Rijn (1606–1669) was the greatest master of the Dutch Golden Age and one of the supreme painters in Western history. Celebrated for his extraordinary command of light and shadow and his psychological depth, his works — including *The Night Watch* and *The Return of the Prodigal Son* — have never been surpassed.
author: EduWiki Team

title: Johann Sebastian Bach
summary: Johann Sebastian Bach (1685–1750) was the supreme master of Baroque music and, by the judgment of most musicians, the greatest composer who ever lived. His *Brandenburg Concertos*, *St. Matthew Passion*, *Well-Tempered Clavier*, and *Mass in B Minor* represent the summit of contrapuntal technique and the deepest musical expression of Christian faith.
author: EduWiki Team

title: Wolfgang Amadeus Mozart
summary: Wolfgang Amadeus Mozart (1756–1791) was the supreme genius of the Classical era in music — a prodigy who produced in his brief 35 years an unsurpassed body of operas (*Don Giovanni*, *The Marriage of Figaro*, *The Magic Flute*), symphonies, concertos, and sacred works that represent one of the highest peaks of Western civilization.
author: EduWiki Team

title: Cleopatra VII
summary: Cleopatra VII (69–30 BC) was the last active ruler of the Ptolemaic Kingdom of Egypt — a brilliant, multilingual queen whose alliances with Julius Caesar and Mark Antony shaped the final decades of the Roman Republic.
author: EduWiki Team

title: Hammurabi
summary: Hammurabi (c. 1810–1750 BC) was the sixth king of the First Babylonian Empire, remembered for the Code of Hammurabi — one of the earliest and most complete written legal codes in history.
author: EduWiki Team

title: Pericles
summary: Pericles (c. 495–429 BC) was the greatest statesman of ancient Athens — the architect of Athenian democracy and the patron of the Golden Age that produced the Parthenon, Greek drama, and classical philosophy.
author: EduWiki Team

title: Hannibal Barca
summary: Hannibal Barca (247–183 BC) was the Carthaginian general widely regarded as one of the greatest military commanders in history, famous for crossing the Alps and his devastating victory at the Battle of Cannae.
author: EduWiki Team

title: Augustus Caesar
summary: Augustus Caesar (63 BC–AD 14) was the first Roman Emperor whose long reign established the Pax Romana — the era of peace and unity into which Jesus Christ was born.
author: EduWiki Team

title: Archimedes
summary: Archimedes of Syracuse (c. 287–212 BC) was the greatest mathematician and inventor of the ancient world, whose discoveries in mathematics and physics anticipated calculus and laid the foundations of mechanics and fluid dynamics.
author: EduWiki Team

title: Ramesses II
summary: Ramesses II (c. 1303–1213 BC), known as Ramesses the Great, was the most powerful pharaoh of ancient Egypt whose 66-year reign saw monumental building projects, military campaigns, and is connected by many scholars to the biblical Exodus.
author: EduWiki Team

title: Thucydides
summary: Thucydides (c. 460–400 BC) was the Athenian historian and general whose account of the Peloponnesian War established the foundations of modern historical writing through his insistence on eyewitness evidence and rational analysis.
author: EduWiki Team

title: Herodotus
summary: Herodotus (c. 484–425 BC), called the Father of History, was the first person to systematically investigate and record the past, producing the Histories — a sweeping account of the Greco-Persian Wars and the ancient world.
author: EduWiki Team

title: Constantine the Great
summary: Constantine the Great (c. AD 272–337) was the first Roman Emperor to embrace Christianity, whose Edict of Milan legalized the faith and whose convening of the Council of Nicaea shaped Christian theology for all time.
author: EduWiki Team

title: Charlemagne
summary: Charlemagne (c. 747–814), King of the Franks and first Holy Roman Emperor, united most of Western Europe, championed Christianity and education, and launched the Carolingian Renaissance that laid the foundations for medieval civilization.
author: EduWiki Team

title: Joan of Arc
summary: Joan of Arc (c. 1412–1431) was a French peasant girl who, claiming divine guidance, led France to victory in the Hundred Years' War, secured the coronation of Charles VII, and was burned at the stake before being canonized as a saint in 1920.
author: EduWiki Team

title: Magna Carta
summary: The Magna Carta (1215), the Great Charter forced upon King John of England by rebellious barons, established for the first time that the king was subject to the rule of law and laid the foundational principles of constitutional government.
author: EduWiki Team

title: The Silk Road
summary: The Silk Road was the ancient network of trade routes connecting China to the Mediterranean world across Central Asia, active for over a millennium, carrying silk, spices, ideas, and religions between civilizations.
author: EduWiki Team

title: Age of Exploration
summary: The Age of Exploration (15th–17th centuries) was the era when European navigators like Columbus, Magellan, and Vasco da Gama opened sea routes to the Americas, Africa, and Asia, transforming global trade, culture, and the spread of Christianity.
author: EduWiki Team

title: Galileo Galilei
summary: Galileo Galilei (1564–1642) was the Italian astronomer and physicist who improved the telescope, confirmed heliocentrism, pioneered the experimental method, and whose conflict with the Church has been widely misunderstood.
author: EduWiki Team

title: Ludwig van Beethoven
summary: Ludwig van Beethoven (1770–1827) was the German composer whose nine symphonies, piano sonatas, and string quartets represent the pinnacle of Western classical music, composed in triumph over progressive and total deafness.
author: EduWiki Team

title: Greek Mythology
summary: Greek mythology is the rich body of stories about gods, heroes, and the cosmos that formed the religious and cultural foundation of ancient Greek civilization and profoundly shaped Western literature, art, and thought.
author: EduWiki Team

title: The Bill of Rights
summary: The Bill of Rights (1791), the first ten amendments to the U.S. Constitution, guarantees fundamental liberties including freedom of speech, religion, press, and assembly, as well as the right to bear arms, due process, and reserved powers to the states.
author: EduWiki Team

title: Mountains
summary: Mountains — from the Alps to the Himalayas to the Rockies — are the great elevated landforms of the Earth, shaped by tectonic forces, profoundly influential in human history, and central to the biblical narrative as places where heaven and earth meet.
author: EduWiki Team

title: Marco Polo
summary: Marco Polo (1254–1324) was the Venetian merchant whose 24-year journey to the court of Kublai Khan in China and whose written account, The Travels of Marco Polo, opened European eyes to the wonders of the Far East and inspired the Age of Exploration.
author: EduWiki Team

title: Gothic Architecture
summary: Gothic architecture, the medieval building style that produced the great cathedrals of Europe — Chartres, Notre-Dame, Canterbury — characterized by pointed arches, ribbed vaults, flying buttresses, and soaring stained-glass windows as an act of worship.
author: EduWiki Team

title: The Scientific Revolution
summary: The Scientific Revolution (c. 1543–1687) was the transformative period when Copernicus, Galileo, Kepler, and Newton overturned the ancient Ptolemaic worldview and established the methods and principles of modern science.
author: EduWiki Team

title: Medieval Literature
summary: Medieval literature encompasses the rich body of writing from the fall of Rome to the Renaissance (c. 500–1500 AD), including Beowulf, the Divine Comedy, The Canterbury Tales, and the Arthurian romances, shaped by Christian faith and classical inheritance.
author: EduWiki Team

title: Byzantine Empire
summary: The Byzantine Empire (330–1453 AD), the eastern continuation of the Roman Empire centered at Constantinople, preserved classical learning, produced magnificent Christian art and architecture, and stood as the great bulwark of Christianity for a thousand years.
author: EduWiki Team
